PARAGRAPH.STRING: (from Aimara, meaning "golden eagle") is the highest peak in the Cordillera Real (part of the Cordillera Oriental, a subrange of the Andes) of western Bolivia.
lies just south of La Paz at the eastern edge of the Altiplano.

is the second highest peak in Bolivia, after Nevado Sajama, and the eighteenth highest peak in South America. The snow line lies at about 4,570 metres (15,000 ft) above sea level, and glaciers are found on the northern face at 4,983 m (16,350 ft).
has four main peaks; the highest is the south summit, Nevado Illimani, which is a popular ascent for mountain climbers.
is composed primarily of granodiorite, intruded during the Cenozoic era into the sedimentary rock which forms the bulk of the Cordillera Real.
is quite visible from the city of La Paz and
has been the subject of many local songs, most importantly "Illimani", with the following refrain: "Illimani, Illimani, sentinela de La Paz! Illimani, Illimani, patrimonio de Bolivia!"

was first attempted in 1877 by C. Wiener, J. de Grumkow, and J. C. Ocampo. They failed to reach the main summit, but did reach a southeastern subsummit. In 1898, British climber William Martin Conway and two Swiss guides, A. Maquignaz and L. Pellissier, made the first recorded ascent of
, again from the southeast. (They found a piece of Aimara rope at over 6,000 m (20,000 ft), so an earlier ascent cannot be completely discounted.)

climbs the west ridge of the main summit. It was first climbed in 1940, by the Germans R. Boetcher, F. Fritz, and W. Kuehn, and is graded French PD+/AD-.[5]. This route usually requires four days, whereas the summit is reached in the morning of the third day.
